awd_titl_txt: Cellular crowding effects on biomolecular stability and dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The research will connect the highly detailed atomistic views of the interior of biological cells with their overall functional behavior. The ultimate outcome is a model of biological cells based on basic physical principles that can be queried to gain a comprehensive understanding of biological processes across a wide range of scales. The research at interdisciplinary boundaries between physics, chemistry, and biochemistry and between simulation, modeling, and experiment provides unique opportunities for training future generations of scientists. The involvement of undergraduate students is a central theme. Teams of undergraduate students from different disciplines will come together under co-mentorship by a graduate student and postdoctoral researcher to begin first research experiences with a strong interdisciplinary perspective. The involvement of women and underrepresented minorities is a major focus.


Cellular environments consist of dense, heterogeneous solutions of biomolecules where interactions are unavoidable yet molecules have to remain fluid and in their native states to carry out biological function. Computer simulations are combined with spectroscopic experiments to characterize the effects of crowding on biomolecular dynamics, stability, and diffusive properties. Dense protein solutions are studied along with systems involving membranes, chromosomal DNA structures, and metabolites. The focus of this project is on characterizing the transient interactions that occur under such conditions and how they affect biomolecular behavior. That insight will allow the construction of predictive models that can relate protein chemistry to dynamic and diffusive behavior, and ultimately biological function, under in vivo conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most of biology fundamentally involves protein and nucleic acid molecules interacting inside cells. The total concentration of molecules inside cells is very high resulting in molecular crowding. Consequently, frequent interactions between proteins and nucleic acids are unavoidable inside cells. Some of those interactions are important for specific functions, but most interactions are essentially random, transient encounters. The ultimate goal of this project is on understanding how such non-specific transient interactions may impact the behavior of proteins and nucleic acids and their ability to carry out biological functions.

The scientific approach taken here involves a closely integrated collaboration between biophysical experiments and computer modeling and simulations. The simulations are used to interpret experimental measurements in terms of molecular behavior and interactions, whereas the experiments in turn validate predictions from the simulations. Together this results in a comprehensive detailed view of how proteins and nucleic acids interact and behave under highly concentrated conditions as those encountered inside cells.

Transient interactions were studied based on model systems. In one system, mixtures of two small proteins, villin or SH3 together with protein G, were studied spectroscopically and via simulations to map out differences in strengths of interactions and preferences for interacting at different areas of the molecular surfaces. This analysis provided details into the nature of transient interactions and established a new protocol for obtaining such detailed information via an integrated experimental and computational approach. 

In other model systems, mixtures of proteins or peptides with RNA were studied with respect to their tendency to spontaneously phase separate into highly concentrated liquid droplets. While such phase separation is well-known for certain types of proteins and RNA, we demonstrated that this is a more general phenomenon that may occur with a wide range of molecules from globular proteins and RNA to very short peptide and RNA fragments. Phase separation was visualized experimentally via microscopy whereas computer simulations with newly developed simplified models allowed us to reach the time and spatial scales on which phase separation occurs.

Computer simulations were also applied to study transient interactions in more complex systems that resemble biological environments more closely. One focus was on the behavior of concentrated proteins near membranes that surround biological cells. Another focus was on interactions between proteins and DNA and the impact on DNA structure and dynamics. Together these studies have advanced our understanding of how proteins and nucleic acids interact in highly concentrated cellular environments.

 

This project has had broader impacts on the training of the workforce in STEM disciplines. Trainees from undergraduate students to graduate students and postdoctoral researchers were involved in this project and many have already advanced in their careers as a result of the training during this project. A significant number of project participants are female and come from other groups that are traditionally underrepresented in STEM disciplines. The project also enabled the development of a new curriculum for introductory physics for life science students that emphasizes active learning techniques and includes laboratory activities.
